segments.en: Linked Discourses 22
1. Nakula’s Father
5. Development of Immersion
So I have heard.
At Sāvatthī.
“Mendicants, develop immersion.
A mendicant who has immersion truly understands.
What do they truly understand?

segments.pli: Rūpassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca, vedanāya samudayañca atthaṅgamañca, saññāya samudayañca atthaṅgamañca, saṅkhārānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca, viññāṇassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca.
segments.en: The origin and ending of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

segments.pli: Ko ca, bhikkhave, rūpassa samudayo, ko vedanāya samudayo, ko saññāya samudayo, ko saṅkhārānaṃ samudayo, ko viññāṇassa samudayo?
segments.en: And what is the origin of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging.
What do they approve, welcome, and keep clinging to?
They approve, welcome, and keep clinging to form.

segments.pli: Tassa rūpaṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato uppajjati nandī.
segments.en: This gives rise to relishing.
Relishing forms is grasping.
Their grasping is a condition for continued existence.
Continued existence is a condition for rebirth.
Rebirth is a condition that gives rise to old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
They approve, welcome, and keep clinging to feeling …
perception …
choices …
consciousness.

segments.pli: Tassa viññāṇaṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato uppajjati nandī.
segments.en: This gives rise to relishing.
Relishing consciousness is grasping.
Their grasping is a condition for continued existence.
Continued existence is a condition for rebirth.
Rebirth is a condition that gives rise to old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
This is the origin of form,
feeling,
perception,
choices,
and consciousness.

segments.pli: Ko ca, bhikkhave, rūpassa atthaṅgamo, ko vedanāya …
segments.en: And what is the ending of form, feeling,
perception,
choices,
and consciousness?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, or keep clinging.
What don’t they approve, welcome, or keep clinging to?
They don’t approve, welcome, or keep clinging to form.

segments.pli: Tassa rūpaṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato yā rūpe nandī sā nirujjhati.
segments.en: As a result, relishing of form ceases.
When that relishing ceases, grasping ceases.
When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. …
That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.
They don’t approve, welcome, or keep clinging to feeling …

segments.pli: Tassa vedanaṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato yā vedanāya nandī sā nirujjhati.

segments.en: perception …
choices …

segments.pli: Tassa saṅkhāre anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato yā saṅkhāresu nandī sā nirujjhati.

segments.en: consciousness.

segments.pli: Tassa viññāṇaṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato yā viññāṇe nandī sā nirujjhati.
segments.en: As a result, relishing of consciousness ceases.
When that relishing ceases, grasping ceases. …
That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, rūpassa atthaṅgamo, ayaṃ vedanāya atthaṅgamo, ayaṃ saññāya atthaṅgamo, ayaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ atthaṅgamo, ayaṃ viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo”ti.
segments.en: This is the ending of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.”

suttaplex.blurb: A mendicant should develop immersion (samādhi) in order to truly understand the origin and ending of the five aggregates.
